questions.question_text:
During audit fieldwork, an IS auditor learns that employees are allowed to connect their personal devices to company-owned computers. How can the auditor
BEST validate that appropriate security controls are in place to prevent data loss?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Verify the data loss prevention (DLP) tool is properly configured by the organization. This is the most direct and effective method to validate real-time prevention and monitoring of data loss, especially regarding unauthorized data transfers to personal devices.

Selected Answer: D
BEST practical test: D. Conduct a walk-through to view results of an employee plugging in a device to transfer confidential data.

Selected Answer: A
This is the most effective approach because a properly configured DLP tool can detect, prevent, and alert on unauthorized data transfers, including those involving personal devices. It directly addresses the risk of data loss by ensuring the system is actively monitoring and controlling sensitive information when employees connect personal devices to company-owned computers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be of MOST concern for an IS auditor evaluating the design of an organization's incident management processes?

discussion.content: A. Prioritization criteria are not defined.

Selected Answer: A
the absence of defined prioritization criteria is the most concerning finding as it can significantly hinder the organization's ability to respond to incidents effectively and efficiently, potentially leading to escalated consequences and prolonged recovery times.

Selected Answer: A
The prioritization of incidents is crucial in incident management. Without defined prioritization criteria, there is a risk that critical incidents may not be addressed in a timely manner, potentially leading to extended downtime, loss of productivity, or other negative impacts on the business.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: C
C. Expected time to resolve incidents is not specified.

The expected time to resolve incidents is a critical aspect of incident management. It helps establish clear service level agreements (SLAs) and expectations regarding incident resolution times. Without specified resolution timeframes, incidents may linger unresolved for extended periods, leading to potential disruptions, security breaches, and dissatisfied stakeholders. This lack of clarity can undermine the effectiveness of incident management processes and compromise the organization's security and operational stability.
